questions.text: False about Elective tracheostomy is/are all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Vertical midline incision from the thyroid cartilage to the suprasternal notch

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical incision is made on 2nd,3rd,4th tracheal rings

options.label: C
options.text: The transverse incision may be used in the elective situation

options.label: D
options.text: Incision continued down between the infrahyoid muscles

questions.correct_answer: C. The transverse incision may be used in the elective situation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The transverse incision may be used in the elective situation Emergency tracheostomy : A vertical midline incision is made from the inferior aspect of the thyroid cartilage to the suprasternal notch and continues down between the infrahyoid muscles. The operator should feel cared for the cricoid cartilage using the free hand's index finger while retracting the skin edges by pressure applied by the thumb and middle finger. Should additional equipment and more time be available once the cricoid cartilage has been identified, blunt finger dissection inferiorly can mobilize the thyroid isthmus, which should be clipped and divided, clearing the trachea before making a vertical incision through the 2nd to 4th rings. Elective tracheostomy: A transverse incision may be used in the elective situation. The tracheal isthmus is divided carefully and oversewn and tension sutures have placed on either side of the tracheal fenestration in children. A Bjork flap may be used in adults.

Highyeild:

Elective surgical procedures offer complete airway control, careful tube placement, and reduced complications. The patient is positioned with a head extension and sandbag under the shoulders. No head rotation or overextension in children. The transverse incision is used in elective situations. Thyroid isthmus divided and oversewn, tension sutures placed in children. Bjork flap may be used in adults, with advantages outweighing potential disadvantages. An inferiorly-based flap starts with an incision between the first and third tracheal rings. Avoid damage to the first tracheal ring to reduce subglottic stenosis risk. Stay suture inserted around the cartilage at the free edge of the flap. Lateral incisions are made in the caudal direction through two tracheal rings to create a flap. Stay suture can be attached and taped to the chest wall or flap sutured to the edge of the skin incision.

Extraedge:

Pediatric patient: a vertical incision made between second and third tracheal rings. Before the tracheal incision, vertical stay sutures are placed lateral to midline through tracheal rings. Stay sutures provide traction and allow rapid reinsertion of the tracheostomy tube. Stick to the midline during dissection to avoid the risk of pneumothorax due to pleura cupula.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presented with stridor, and the resident on duty performed a cricothyrotomy to improve the ventilation. After the appropriate cricothyrotomy, while he was observing the patient, the consultant came for rounds and told him to convert it to tracheostomy. Which of the following would be the correct explanation for the change in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To avoid subglottic stenosis Cricothyroidotomy has the advantages of speed and ease, requiring minimal equipment and surgical expertise, and has excellent value in the emergency setting when conditions are not optimal for performing a tracheostomy. The patient’s neck is extended, and the area between the prominence of the thyroid cartilage and the cricoid cartilage below is palpated with the free hand's index finger. A vertical skin incision is recommended in an emergency, with dissection rapidly carried down to the cricothyroid membrane. A 1-cm transverse incision is made through the membrane immediately above the cricoid cartilage As soon as possible, the cricothyroidotomy should be converted to a tracheostomy . Although there is debate about the frequency of subglottic stenosis following this procedure, there is general agreement that it is much increased if any long-term ventilation is undertaken via even a modestly size tracheostomy tube through the cricothyroid membrane.

Highyeild:

Cricothyroidotomy is done through the cricothyroid membrane. The membrane connects the thyroid cartilage to the cricoid cartilage. The cricothyroid artery and vein can cover the membrane, the pyramidal lobe of the thyroid gland, and lymph nodes. Precise identification of the membrane is essential to avoid damaging nearby structures. The procedure involves extending the patient's neck and palpating the area between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage. The "laryngeal handshake technique" can be used to locate the membrane if necessary.

Extraedge:

Cricothyroidotomy can use a scalpel or cannulae. The fastest and most reliable method is the scalpel-bougie tube technique. The procedure requires a number 10 blade, bougie, and cuffed endotracheal tube, with the patient receiving 100% oxygen and complete neuromuscular blockade. A vertical skin incision is recommended, followed by a 1-cm transverse incision through the membrane above the cricoid cartilage. An artery forceps, bougie, dilator, or tracheal hook can improve aperture and tube insertion. Cannula cricothyroidotomy can use a narrow-bore or wide-bore cannula. Both techniques can lead to complications such as kinking of the cannula, device displacement, and barotrauma.

Lymphangioma Cystic hygromas usually present in the neonate or early infancy and occasionally may present at birth and be so large as to obstruct labor. The cysts are filled with clear lymph and lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance. The swelling may be bilateral, soft, and partially compressible, visibly increasing in size when the child coughs or cries. The characteristic that distinguishes it from all other neck swellings is that it is brilliantly translucent .

Highyeild:

Cystic hygromas typically appear in babies or infants. They can sometimes be large enough to cause problems during labor. The cysts are filled with clear lymph and have a mosaic-like lining. The swelling usually appears in the neck and can spread to the face, tongue, and mouth floor. The swelling is soft, can be compressed partially, and grows visibly during coughing or crying. A distinguishing feature of cystic hygromas is their bright transillumination. They can also occur in the cheek, axilla, groin, and mediastinum, but this is rare.

Extraedge:

Complete excision of the cyst is the best treatment option. Early intervention is ideal. Sclerosing agent injection is an alternative, but complete resolution is complex due to its multicystic nature.

questions.text: A neonate presents with swelling in the neck after an obstructed labour, the swelling is compressible, brilliantly trans-illuminant, visibly increasing in size while the child is coughing or crying. Which of the following is the definitive management for the neonate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Surgical excision Cystic hygromas usually occur in the neck and may involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, and floor of mouth areas. The cheek, axilla, groin, and mediastinum are other less frequent sites for cystic hygroma. Sometimes the cyst expands rapidly, and occasionally respiratory difficulty ensues, requiring immediate aspiration and occasionally a tracheostomy. The cyst may become infected. Definitive treatment involving complete cyst excision at an early stage is best. Injection of a sclerosing agent is an alternative strategy and may reduce the size of the cyst.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady came to the outpatient clinic with a history of palpitation and tremors and loss of weight despite a good appetite. Her pulse rate was 112/min, bp-140/70. No other symptoms. Which will be the single most appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TSH The history shows that the patient has primary hyperthyroidism: pulse, tremor, tachycardia, fatigue, emotional lability, and hyperkinesis. The most common GI symptoms are the frequency of bowel movements and diarrhea. The patient also has tachycardia of 112/min and loss of weight despite a good appetite which is also a sign of hyperthyroidism. Widened pulse pressure also supports the diagnosis. A suppressed TSH diagnoses hyperthyroidism with or without elevated free T3 or T4. If eye signs are present, generally, other tests are not needed. If absent, an I 123 uptake scan should be performed. TSH is the single most appropriate investigation for this patient. The average value of TSH is 0.5-5 µu/ml. Ultrasensitive TSH assays are most sensitive and specific in diagnosing hyper and hypothyroidism. Newer lab assays can detect TSH as low as 0.0004 mIU/ml.

Highyeild:

Graves' disease and toxic nodular goiters increase hormone production, while thyroiditis and nonthyroid gland-related conditions release the stored hormone. Graves' disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and solitary toxic nodules are the most critical hyperthyroidism conditions for surgery. The difference between them and other hyperthyroidism conditions can be determined by a RAIU test.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. T3 levels are normal or increased in hyperthyroidism. Hence it must be more than a single appropriate test. If free T3 levels are increased with standard T4, it could be an early sign of Graves disease. Option: B. T4 can be normal or increased in hyperthyroidism Option: D. Free t3 – most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of early hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady presented with swelling in front of the neck, which moves with deglutition and does not move with tongue protrusion. She has normal thyroid function tests. She also has symptoms of dysphagia. Which is the single most important test in the evaluation of thyroid masses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

FNAC The description of swelling is related to thyroid enlargement- goiter , swelling in front of the neck, moves with deglutition, and does not move with tongue protrusion. Hence we are dealing with a patient with SNG. TFT- indicates the absence of disease / toxic goiter typically. Giving TFT as an option needs to be clarified. An iodine scan is done to locate ectopic/metastatic thyroid or toxicity with nodularity. No such indication is present here. She has a pressure symptom which is one of the symptoms of thyroid malignancy. Pressure symptoms include dysphagia- difficulty in swelling due to enlargement of lateral lobes, dyspnoea- due to tracheal infiltration, and dysphonia- due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement. Hence to evaluate a thyroid nodule FNAC is the most critical test. FNAC is the single important test. It can be performed with or without USG guidance. Bethesda criteria are used for cytological classification of the management of thyroid nodules.

Highyeild:

FNAC is the most crucial test for thyroid mass evaluation Ultrasound guidance is recommended for difficult-to-palpate nodules, recurring cystic or solid-cystic nodules, and multinodular goiters A 23-gauge needle was inserted into the group; several passes were made while aspirating Cells were placed on prelabeled dry glass slides and some in a 70% alcohol solution; a sample was placed in a 90% alcohol solution for cytospin or cell pellet Slides stained and examined under the microscope Bloody aspirate requires the repositioning and repeating biopsy with a finer needle (25- to 30-gauge)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. TFT is a function test that indicates only hyper or hypothyroidism Option: C. USG helps detect nonpalpable thyroid nodules Option: D. Core biopsy is indicated only in lymphoma and anaplastic carcinoma.

Extraedge:

Most thyroid nodule patients are euthyroid. Determining blood TSH levels is helpful. The risk of malignancy in a hyperthyroid patient with a nodule is around 1% Serum Tg levels are not useful for differentiating benign from malignant nodules but helpful for following up post-thyroidectomy patients and non-operative management Serum calcitonin levels should be obtained in patients with MTC or a family history of MTC/MEN2 RET oncogene mutations testing and 24-hour urine collection are needed for patients with MTC to rule out pheochromocytoma 10% of familial MTC and MEN2A patients have de novo RET mutations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with thyroid swelling, which was initially small in size and gradually progressive to attain the present size. His sleeping pulse rate was normal. TFT showed normal functioning of the thyroid. FNAC revealed Bethesda type 4. What would be the next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lobectomy The patient typically has longstanding thyroid swelling. Since the TFT shows average results, the next step is to rule out malignancy. FNAC results – Bethesda 4 correlates with a follicular or suspicious follicular neoplasm. The next step of Bethesda 4 is lobectomy. Bethesda classification: I-Non diagnostic – repeat FNAC with USG guidance II-Benign- cyst ( aspirate), colloid nodule (observe) III-Atypia of undetermined significance (AUS)/ follicular lesion of unknown significance(flu)- repeat FNAC IV-Follicular neoplasm or suspicious follicular- lobectomy V-Suspicious for malignancy- lobectomy / near- total/total thyroidectomy VI-Malignant- near-total / total thyroidectomy

Highyeild:

Classification of fine-needle aspiration cytology reports. Thy1 Non-diagnostic Thylc Non-diagnostic cystic Thy2 Non-neoplastic Thy3 Follicular Thy4 Suspicious of malignancy Thy5 Malignant

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. R epeat FNAC - Bethesda 3 Option: B . Repeat FNAC with USG guidance- Bethesda 1 Option: D. observe - Bethesda 2- colloid nodule

Extraedge:

FNAB is the most important test for thyroid mass evaluation Ultrasound guidance is recommended for difficult-to-palpate nodules, recurring cystic or solid-cystic nodules, and multinodular goiters A 23-gauge needle was inserted into the group; several passes were made while aspirating Cells were placed on prelabeled dry glass slides and some in a 70% alcohol solution. A sample placed in a 90% alcohol solution for cytospin or cell pellet Slides stained and examined under the microscope Bloody aspirate requires the repositioning and repeating biopsy with a finer needle (25- to 30-gauge)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came to the Surgery OPD with neck swelling. On examination, the swelling was fluctuant, non-tender, and moved with swallowing and with tongue protrusion. The patient was evaluated and cleared for surgery. What is the best treatment done for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sistrunk Surgery The case profile described is that of a Thyroglossal Cyst. It is the most commonly encountered congenital cervical anomaly. The thyroid gland arises as an outpouching of the primitive foregut; endoderm cells in the floor of the pharyngeal anlage thicken to form the medial thyroid anlage that descends in the neck. During its descent, the anlage remains connected to the foramen cecum via an epithelial-lined tube known as the thyroglossal duct. The duct disappears by the eighth week of gestation. Rarely, the thyroglossal duct may persist in whole or in part. 80% thyroglossal duct cysts are found in juxtaposition to the hyoid bone. The Sistrunk operation consists of an en-bloc cystectomy and excision of the central hyoid bone to minimize recurrence.

Highyeild:

Treatment for thyroglossal duct cysts involves Sistrunk operation , which includes bloc cystectomy and central hyoid bone excision. Approximately 1% of cysts are cancerous, usually papillary type Total thyroidectomy is advised for patients with large tumors, additional thyroid nodules, and evidence of invasion or metastases Squamous, Hürthle cell, and anaplastic cancers are rare Medullary thyroid cancers are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A. Cystectomy must be paired with the central hyoid bone excision to minimize recurrence. Option B. Total Thyroidectomy is only considered in cases where thyroglossal duct cysts contain cancer with either large tumors, additional thyroid nodules, evidence of cyst wall invasion, or lymph node metastases. Option C . Surgical Drainage of the cyst leads to thyroglossal duct sinuses, so Incision and drainage are not done.

Extraedge:

The thyroglossal cyst is lined by pseudostratified columnar and squamous epithelium. Heterotopic thyroid tissue is present in 20% of cases.

questions.text: In a post-operative case of Thyroidectomy, difficulties with achieving high pitch and vocal projection, and volume were noted by the patient. What is truly related to the anatomical basis of this problem?

options.label: A
options.text: Injury to this nerve is commonly at Berry’s Ligament due to close proximity.

options.label: B
options.text: The injured nerve supplies all muscles of the Larynx except the Cricothyroid.

options.label: C
options.text: Injury to this nerve can be due to improper ligation of the superior thyroid artery.

options.label: D
options.text: B/L injury can lead to the requirement of tracheostomy for airway management.

questions.correct_answer: C. Injury to this nerve can be due to improper ligation of the superior thyroid artery.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Injury to this nerve can be due to improper ligation of the superior thyroid artery. The nerve injured in this case is the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN). The EBSLN innervates the cricothyroid muscles and contributes to vocal fold tone and tension. EBSLN injury leads to difficulty achieving high pitch, vocal projection, and volume. The recurrent laryngeal Nerve (RLN) is the more critical nerve and innervates the motor function of all of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles except for the cricothyroid. The RLN is most vulnerable to injury in the vicinity of the ligament of Berry. EBSLN runs quite close to the superior pole vessels and the upper thyroid lobe, so care must be taken when ligating and dividing the plates during thyroidectomy.

Highyeild:

RLNs are usually found at the cricoid cartilage level. Parathyroids are near the intersection of the inferior thyroid artery and the RLN, within 1 cm. The ligament of Berry is a vulnerable area for RLN injury, and any bleeding should be controlled gently before identifying and ligating the vessel. Avoid using electrocautery near the RLN. The thyroid can be separated from the trachea by sharp dissection once the ligament is divided.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. RLN is typically related to the tubercle of Zuckerkandl, which lies just anterior and lateral to the nerve. There is an intimate relationship between the RLN, Berry ligament, and the inferior thyroid artery at the level of the cricoid cartilage. Option: B. Recurrent laryngeal Nerve (RLN) innervates the motor function of all of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles except for the cricothyroid. Option: D. Bilateral RLN injury with subsequent bilateral vocal fold paralysis may require tracheostomy for airway control if the paralyzed vocal folds rest in a median position preventing adequate air exchange.

Extraedge:

Dissect, skeletonize, ligate, and divide inferior thyroid vessels as close to the surface of the thyroid gland. This minimizes the devascularization of parathyroids and injury to RLN. Extracapsular dissection is recommended.

questions.text: A patient with a Unilateral Thyroid Nodule came for a workup, and a Radioisotope IODINE-123 Scan was planned. Of the following different scans, which has the MOST chance of being a Malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B The uptake by the thyroid of a low dose of either Radio - labeled IODINE (123-I) or the cheaper technetium (99mTc) will demonstrate the distribution of activity in the whole gland. The risk of malignancy is higher in “cold” lesions (20%) compared to “hot” or “warm” lesions (< 5%). Iodine-123 and iodine-131 are used to image the thyroid gland. It is a COLD NODULE, and though most of them (~80%) are Benign, they carry a higher risk of malignancy (~20%).

Highyeild:

Iodine-123 emits low-dose radiation, has a 12-14 hour half-life, and is used for lingual thyroids or goiters. Iodine-131 emits higher-dose radiation, has an 8-10 day half-life, and is used for differentiated thyroid cancers to screen and treat metastatic disease. Technetium Tc 99m pertechnetate is used for thyroid evaluation, has a shorter half-life, and is sensitive to nodal metastases.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Is a Toxic Multinodular Goiter Imaging. Uptake increases, showing multiple nodules with increased uptake and suppression of the remaining gland. Option: C. It is a Graves' Disease Scan. An elevated uptake, with a diffusely enlarged gland, confirms the diagnosis of Graves' disease and helps to differentiate it from other causes of hyperthyroidism. Option: D. Toxic Adenoma scanning shows a "hot" nodule with suppression of the rest of the thyroid gland. These nodules are rarely malignant.

Extraedge:

18F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (PET) combined with computed tomography (CT) is used to screen for metastases in thyroid cancer patients. PET scans are not routinely used in thyroid nodule evaluation but can show clinically occult thyroid lesions. Rates of malignancy in these lesions range from 14% to 63%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman underwent a total thyroidectomy, and, after a few weeks, came for a follow-up. Upon investigating the patient, she was found to have Hypoparathyroidism. Improper handling of which anatomical structure is responsible for this complication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior Thyroid Artery The patient suffers from Hypoparathyroidism due to Improper ligation of the Inferior Thyroid artery. The blood supply of both the superior and inferior parathyroid glands arises from the inferior thyroidal artery in most cases. All normal parathyroid glands should be carefully dissected and swept away from the thyroid on as broad a vascular pedicle as possible in order to prevent devascularization. The inferior thyroid vessels are dissected, skeletonized, ligated, and divided as close to the surface of the thyroid gland as possible to minimize devascularization of the parathyroids or injury to the RLN.

Highyeild:

Removal of parathyroid glands or damage to end arteries causes hypoparathyroidism Vascular injury is more important than removal Permanent hypoparathyroidism incidence less than 1% Symptoms present dramatically 2-5 days post-op Delayed onset or asymptomatic cases very rare

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . The superior pole vessels are individually isolated, ligated, and divided. When supplying the Parathyroid gland, in some variations, they only supply the Upper Parathyroid. So are not responsible for Hypoparathyroidism. Option: B. Middle Thyroid Vein is the first to be identified and ligated and is not responsible for the loss of the Parathyroid Gland. Option: C. Thyroid Ima artery is a variable artery & not responsible for blood supply to the Parathyroid.

Extraedge:

Total thyroidectomy increases risk, lobectomy usually not an issue Total thyroidectomy with neck dissection high risk for parathyroid damage Only do when metastatic or high risk of occult disease in lymph nodes

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the surgery OPD with complaints of swelling in the neck. Ultrasonography and Blood investigations were advised to the patient. Nuclear Scintigraphy would be needed in which of the following cases:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperthyroidism In cases of thyroid involvement, USG, and Blood investigations are now advanced enough to diagnose most conditions. A thyroid uptake scan is useful for the differential diagnosis of hyperthyroidism whether increased radiotracer uptake occurs diffusely throughout the gland as in the case of Graves’ disease or more discrete “hot” nodules in cases of solitary toxic adenoma or a toxic multinodular goiter (TMG).

Highyeild:

Hyperthyroidism is a condition characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels in the body. The severity of hyperthyroidism can be classified into two groups: overt and subclinical, with the overt disease being more severe than the subclinical disease. Symptoms: Overt hyperthyroidism includes tremors, heat intolerance, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, increased gastrointestinal motility, muscle weakness, anxiety, and embolic events.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Simple GoiterGoitre develops due to stimulation of the thyroid gland by TSH, either as a result of in response to a chronically low level of circulating thyroid hormones or inappropriate secretion from a microadenoma in the anterior pituitary. No use of Nuclear Scintigraphy for diagnosis. Option: B . Non-toxic thyroid Nodules are best evaluated with USG. USG helps in the risk stratification of thyroid nodules and the detection of suspicious cervical lymphadenopathy. Option: C . The biochemical workup for Hashimoto thyroiditis includes measurement of thyroid function tests and circulating thyroid autoantibodies. USG is optional and can be done.

Extraedge:

Subclinical hyperthyroidism typically has milder manifestations of the same disease symptomatology seen in overt hyperthyroidism. Treatment options for hyperthyroidism include medication, radioactive iodine therapy, and surgery, depending on the underlying cause and severity of the condition.

questions.text: Match the following THYROID FUNCTIONS TEST results with appropriate Pathological states.

options.label: B
options.text: 1- Thyrotoxic, 2- Myxoedema, 3- Thyrotoxic, 4- Suppressive T4 therapy

options.label: C
options.text: 1- Suppressive T4 therapy, 2- Myxoedema, 3- Thyrotoxic, 4-T3 toxicity

questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-Myxedema, 2-Thyrotoxic, 3-Suppressive T4 therapy, 4-T3 toxicity The measurement of TSH and free T4 are the most commonly paired thyroid function tests because of their accurate interpretability in the majority of scenarios, treatment monitoring of thyroid dysfunction. T3 is not as useful for diagnosing hypothyroidism, but it can be useful in conditions such as hyperthyroidism and euthyroid sick syndrome. Is Myxoedema, T3 & T4 are high with TSH low.

Highyeild:

TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) and free T4 (free thyroxine) are the most commonly ordered thyroid function tests because they provide important information about thyroid function. The pituitary gland produces TSH and stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones. Free T4 is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland that helps regulate metabolism.. In most cases, TSH and free T4 levels are sufficient for diagnosing and monitoring thyroid dysfunction, including hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) and hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid). However, in certain conditions, such as euthyroid sick syndrome (a condition in which thyroid hormone levels are abnormal due to non-thyroidal illness), measuring T3 (triiodothyronine) levels may also be useful.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Is Thyrotoxicosis with high T3 & T4. Option: C . T4 therapy causes TSH suppression and HIGH free-T4 & T3. As T4 is converted to T3. Option: D . T3 toxicity causes a Lowering of TSH with a normal T4, as T3 is rapid acting.

Extraedge:

In hyperthyroidism, T3 levels can be elevated even when TSH and free T4 levels are normal. Therefore, measuring T3 levels can be useful in diagnosing hyperthyroidism. Additionally, in some cases of the euthyroid sick syndrome, T3 levels may be low even when TSH and free T4 levels are normal, which can provide important diagnostic information.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding THYROID GLAND FNAC is not TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: FNAC is the investigation of choice for Thyroid Nodules.

options.label: B
options.text: ‘Thy1’ can be reduced by performing an ultrasound-guided FNAC.

options.label: C
options.text: BOTH Thy1 Bethesda & TI-RADS TR1 classes are referring to the non-Diagnostic report.

options.label: D
options.text: FNAC of discrete palpable swelling is classified as an Essential Thyroid Investigation.

questions.correct_answer: C. BOTH Thy1 Bethesda & TI-RADS TR1 classes are referring to the non-Diagnostic report.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BOTH Thy1 Bethesda & TI-RADS TR1 classes are referring to the non-Diagnostic report. Blood Investigations, Imaging, and FNAC carry out Thyroid Gland Evaluation. Thyroid investigations can be essential or optional: Essential Serum: TSH (T3 and T4 if abnormal); thyroid autoantibodies. FNAC of palpable discrete swellings; Ultrasound guidance may reduce the ‘Thy1’ rate. Thy1 is a non-diagnostic report. TR1 is a TIRAD report for Benign Lesions. Optional Corrected serum calcium Serum calcitonin (carcinoembryonic antigen may be used as an alternative screening test for medullary cancer) Imaging: chest radiograph; ultrasound, CT and MRI scan for known cancer, some reoperations and some retrosternal goiters; isotope scan if discrete swelling and toxicity coexist.

Highyeild:

The most crucial test for evaluating thyroid masses is Fine-needle aspiration cytology ( FNAC). Ultrasound guidance is suggested for nodules that are hard to palpate, and for cystic or solid-cystic nodules that reoccur after initial aspiration. A 23-gauge needle is commonly used for FNAC. If the FNAC report is nondiagnostic, the test should be repeated. In complex nodules, the solid portion should be sampled during FNAC. The risk of malignancy in cases with suspicious cytology is approximately 20%. Classification of fine-needle aspiration cytology reports. Thy1 Non-diagnostic Thylc Non-diagnostic cystic Thy2 Non-neoplastic Thy3 Follicular Thy4 Suspicious of malignancy Thy5 Malignant

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. FNAC is an Investigation of Choice for Thyroid Nodules. Option: B. Ultrasound guidance may reduce the 'Thy1' rate in Bethesda Classification of fine-needle aspiration cytology reports. Option: D. FNAC is an essential thyroid investigation.
